title: The Evolution of Animation: From Hand-Drawn Dreams to Digital Realities
subtitle: A Journey Through Animation History

slides.title: The Dawn of Animation
content: Pre-cinematic optical devices (zoetropes, phenakistoscopes)
Early experiments with persistence of vision
First animated sequences in the late 1800s
Émile Reynaud's praxinoscope and Théâtre Optique
slides.image_prompt: A vintage Victorian-era scene showing early animation devices including a zoetrope, phenakistoscope, and praxinoscope arranged on an ornate wooden table. Warm sepia tones with golden lighting, illustrated in a detailed engraving style. Historical accuracy with people in 19th-century clothing interacting with the devices.
slides.visual_style: Vintage sepia illustration, Victorian aesthetic, warm lighting

slides.title: Silent Era Pioneers
content: Winsor McCay's 'Gertie the Dinosaur' (1914)
Felix the Cat: First animated superstar
Walt Disney's early Oswald the Lucky Rabbit
Transition from novelty to storytelling
slides.image_prompt: Black and white illustration featuring iconic silent era characters: Gertie the Dinosaur interacting with Winsor McCay, Felix the Cat winking, and Oswald the Rabbit. Characters appear in various poses with early film strip borders. Art deco geometric patterns in background, reminiscent of 1920s design.
slides.visual_style: Black and white Art Deco, vintage animation cel aesthetic

slides.title: The Golden Age of Animation
content: Disney's 'Snow White' (1937): First feature-length animated film
Warner Bros. Looney Tunes revolutionize comedy
Technicolor brings vibrant worlds to life
Studio system dominance and artistic innovation
slides.image_prompt: Vibrant color scene showcasing Golden Age animation icons: Snow White with the Seven Dwarfs, Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck in classic poses, and other famous characters. Rich Technicolor palette with jewel tones. Background features classic 1930s-40s animation studio elements like drawing boards and animation cels.

slides.title: Television Revolution
content: Hanna-Barbera mass-produce cartoons for TV
Limited animation techniques for cost efficiency
Saturday morning cartoon culture emerges
Global expansion: Japanese anime begins
slides.image_prompt: Split screen composition showing Western TV cartoons like The Flintstones and Scooby-Doo on one side, with early Japanese anime characters like Astro Boy and Speed Racer on the other. Vintage TV set frame elements, bright primary colors, Saturday morning cereal box aesthetic.
slides.visual_style: Mid-century TV aesthetic, bright primary colors, cartoon style

slides.title: Digital Breakthrough
content: Computer animation enters mainstream
Pixar's 'Toy Story' (1995) revolutionizes the industry
CGI blends with traditional techniques
Software democratizes animation creation
slides.image_prompt: Futuristic composition showing Woody and Buzz Lightyear from Toy Story alongside wireframe models and early CGI renderings. Digital grid patterns, pixel elements, and computer interface graphics blend with 3D character models. Blue and purple color scheme representing the digital revolution.
slides.visual_style: Digital aesthetic, 1990s computer graphics, wireframe elements

slides.title: Modern Animation Renaissance
content: 3D animation dominance in features
2D animation finds new artistic expression
Streaming platforms expand opportunities
Global animation styles influence each other
